awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Identifying Fraud in the Cryptocurrency Ecosystem
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance understanding of how cybercrime has been able to flourish in the emerging cryptocurrency economy. Research has revealed cybercrime in the cryptocurrency economy, and the rate of fraud has seemed to increase. By understanding the incentives for crime and by modeling effective regulation, this research will make progress towards upending cryptocurrency-based crime. The project will collect data towards understanding how the underlying incentives work to cause fraudulent behavior and how the ecosystem perpetuates fraud. This work aims to influence public policy on cryptocurrencies, making the cryptocurrency ecosystem safer for consumers. The project will train students in this research area and produce course materials.
 
The project seeks to correct the information asymmetry in the current cryptocurrency ecosystem, whereby consumers cannot tell the difference between a fraud and a legitimate business. There are two parts to this project. The first part will analyze one particular sector of the ecosystem that seems to be rife with speculation: alternative currencies and the corresponding currency exchanges listing the currencies. Each needs the other to be profitable: currencies need to be listed on an exchange to be worth money, and exchanges need currencies to be listed on them to extract fees from their users executing trades and (often) listing fees for each currency. The second part will collect social network data on cryptocurrency-related services at large in order to learn which services have a high probability of being scams and what indicators are correlated with this. The work will compare the propagation of information about legitimate industries and frauds to work towards differentiating the two. The project will take a longitudinal approach towards modeling how the cryptocurrency ecosystem has evolved into its current state, and it will continue to adapt the models as criminals adapt.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The work done in the project provided insight into the cryptocurrency exchange ecosystem, both in terms of how cryptocurrencies are promoted and how code is shared or propagates between multiple cryptocurrency implementations. The publications, data sets, and associated analyses resulting from this research  provide an initial analysis of these factors and provide a foundation for future research on the use of social media and on code sharing in the cryptocurrency ecosystem. These will allow researchers in this space to better understand the innerworkings and relationships between exchanges and the coins listed on those exchanges. Our methodologies and analysis techniques we researched  have broad applicability to other topics in the cryptocurrency ecosystem and cybersecurity writ large. 

In addition, the information and techniques discovered in this research provide a basis for informing public policy as well as for developiong new cryptocurrency analysis tools in other fields. For example, these technique are now available to be used to debunk common metrics used by other researchers in fields like economics and finance that are potentially inaccurate. For example, it is common to use indicators such as the number of twitter followers or the amount of trades of a cryptocurrency without thinking that some coins buy more twitter followers than others and some exchanges fake most of their trades fairly transparently. Our analyses provide the tools needed to create metrics that better capture elements of the cryptocurrency ecosystem.

Finally, the project trained graduate students in the conduct of cryptocurrency research and general research methodologies as part of this program, both through direct mentoring and through a public symposium. Specifically, an international symposium to informa people on issues related to the security of cryptocurrencies was developed and offered, one graduate student graduated and is currently pursuing employment in the U.S. cybersecurity field, and another graduate student is currently continuing the pursuit of her Ph.D. in a related area.


Last Modified: 11/10/2022
Modified by: Patrick G Bridges
